references: Table I displays the top-1 test accuracy of different approaches on four datasets. The hyperparameter μ𝜇\mu in FedIntR, MOON [8], FedProx [5], and FedCKA [9] can be tuned to control the regularization strength in the local training loss. For each approach, we tune the μ𝜇\mu value and report the best results. For FedIntR and FedCKA, we tune μ𝜇\mu from [0.1,1,3,5,10]0.113510[0.1,1,3,5,10] (which covers the range used by the original FedCKA paper). We tune μ𝜇\mu from [0.1,1,5,10]0.11510[0.1,1,5,10] for MOON and [0.001,0.01,0.1,1]0.0010.010.11[0.001,0.01,0.1,1] for FedProx, according to their respective papers. In Table I, we report the corresponding best μ𝜇\mu values in parentheses.

S4.T2.caption: TABLE II: Test accuracy (%) of FedIntR with different μ𝜇\mu values.
S4.T2.table:
\hlineB3 μ𝜇\mu Fashion-MNIST SVHN CIFAR-10 CIFAR-100
\hlineB3 0.1 88.87 86.85 65.23 41.00
1 89.07 85.89 65.66 40.43
3 88.67 87.05 67.23 40.99
5 89.13 87.01 66.99 41.21
10 89.15 87.17 65.89 41.48
\hlineB3
references: Our proposed FedIntR framework achieves superior performance in the SVHN and CIFAR-10 datasets compared to the baseline techniques. For the Fashion-MNIST dataset, both FedIntR and MOON achieve the best performance. FedCKA outperforms FedIntR on the CIFAR-100 dataset, but FedIntR still maintains a comparable performance. There are three plausible explanations for this. (i) For the CIFAR-100 dataset, we employ the ResNet-20 model, which contains fewer number of extraction points for intermediate representations than the CNN model. (ii) The superior performance of FedIntR can be observed more clearly with a higher degree of data heterogeneity, which will be discussed in Section IV-C, where we compare the performance of different techniques on varying degrees of data heterogeneity. (iii) FedIntR is more beneficial from longer training. By default, we set the number of communication rounds as 100, but as we will discuss in Section IV-D, FedIntR performs better with a higher number of training rounds. For reference, we also provide the performance of FedIntR from tuning μ𝜇\mu in Table II.

S4.T3.caption: TABLE III: Test accuracy (%) on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets with different β𝛽\beta values. We tune μ𝜇\mu for each method and the best μ𝜇\mu value is shown in brackets.
S4.T3.table:
\hlineB3 CIFAR-10 CIFAR-100
β=5𝛽5\beta=5 β=0.5𝛽0.5\beta=0.5 β=0.1𝛽0.1\beta=0.1 β=5𝛽5\beta=5 β=0.5𝛽0.5\beta=0.5 β=0.1𝛽0.1\beta=0.1
\hlineB3 FedAvg 68.69 65.82 55.62 40.62 40.43 37.48
FedCKA 68.62 (1) 66.55 (0.1) 55.64 (0.1) 40.40 (0.1) 41.91 (10) 35.73 (10)
FedProx 70.03 (0.01) 65.03 (0.01) 56.55 (0.01) 40.00 (0.001) 39.91 (0.1) 37.38 (0.1)
MOON 69.34 (1) 66.35 (5) 57.60 (1) 40.23 (0.1) 40.46 (0.1) 37.16 (5)
FedIntR 70.66 (5) 67.23 (3) 58.32 (10) 40.06 (0.1) 41.48 (10) 38.24 (0.5)
\hlineB3
references: Table III displays the test accuracy values attained by different approaches on the CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets with β𝛽\beta values of 5, 0.5, and 0.1. Similar to Section IV-B, we tune the μ𝜇\mu value for each approach (shown in parentheses in Table III) and report the best results. For the CIFAR-10 dataset, FedIntR exhibits superior performance over the baseline approaches in all data heterogeneity settings. FedProx has comparable performance to FedIntR when β=5𝛽5\beta=5 (i.e., when the degree of data heterogeneity among the clients is low), but its performance diminishes with a smaller β𝛽\beta value. For the CIFAR-100 dataset, vanilla FedAvg outperforms all other approaches when β=5𝛽5\beta=5. However, as the β𝛽\beta value decreases, incorporating a form of regularization into the local loss can outperform the vanilla FedAvg. With β=0.1𝛽0.1\beta=0.1, our proposed FedIntR significantly outperforms the other approaches. We speculate that fine-grained regularization computed from intermediate representations and layer-wise contributions makes FedIntR more robust in FL environments with high degrees of data heterogeneity.

references: From Table IV, we can observe that vanilla FedAvg outperforms the majority of other approaches in the early training rounds (i.e., T=100𝑇100T=100 and T=200𝑇200T=200) for both N=50𝑁50N=50 and N=100𝑁100N=100 settings. This is due to the fact that the local training loss in FedAvg focuses only on performance improvement, whereas the other approaches include a regularization term with additional objectives. However, with a sufficient number of training rounds, FedIntR with μ=10𝜇10\mu=10 can significantly outperform all other approaches. In the N=50𝑁50N=50 setting, FedIntR (μ=10𝜇10\mu=10) outperforms the second best approach, FedProx, by 1.19% at T=800𝑇800T=800, and in the N=100𝑁100N=100 setting, it outperforms MOON (μ=10𝜇10\mu=10) by 1.45% at T=1000𝑇1000T=1000. Fig. 4 shows the test accuracy values of different methods in each round for the N=100𝑁100N=100 setting.

Average 89.03 85.62 64.20 40.33
\hlineB3
references: In Table V, we compare the performance of FedIntR with and without αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} on four datasets. We can observe that calculating a layer-wise weight αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} for its corresponding representation loss ℓksubscriptℓ𝑘\ell_{k} can significantly improve the performance of the resulting global model. αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} determines the contribution of individual ℓksubscriptℓ𝑘\ell_{k} to the regularization term, enabling FedIntR to perform local training with fine-grained regularization.
